The United States has a highly developed mixed economy. It is the world's
largest economy by nominal GDP and second largest by purchasing power parity
(PPP). As of 2025, it has the world's seventh highest nominal GDP per capita
and ninth highest GDP per capita by PPP. The U.S. accounts for 27% of the
global economy in 2025 in nominal terms, and about 16% in PPP terms. The U.S.
dollar is the currency of record most used in international transactions and
is the world's reserve currency, backed by a large U.S. treasuries market, its
role as the reference standard for the petrodollar system, and its linked
eurodollar. Several countries use it as their official currency and in others
it is the _de facto_ currency. Since the end of World War II, the economy has
achieved relatively steady growth, low unemployment and inflation, and rapid
advances in technology.

The American economy is fueled by high productivity, well-developed
transportation infrastructure, and extensive natural resources. Americans have
the sixth highest average household and employee income among OECD member
states. In 2021, they had the highest median household income among OECD
countries, although the country also had one of the world's highest income
inequalities among the developed countries. The largest U.S. trading partners
are Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, Germany, South Korea, the United Kingdom,
Taiwan, India, and Vietnam. The U.S. is the world's largest importer and
second-largest exporter. It has free trade agreements with several countries,
including Canada and Mexico (through the USMCA), Australia, South Korea,
Israel, and several others that are in effect or under negotiation. The U.S.
has a highly flexible labor market, where the industry adheres to a hire-and-
fire policy, and job security is relatively low. Among OECD nations, the U.S.
has a highly efficient social security system; social expenditure stood at
roughly 30% of GDP.

The United States is the world's largest producer of petroleum, natural gas,
and blood products. In 2016, it was the world's largest trading country, and
second largest manufacturer, with American manufacturing making up a fifth of
the global total. The U.S. has the largest internal market for goods, and also
dominates the services trade. Total U.S. trade was $4.2 trillion in 2018. Of
the world's 500 largest companies, 139 are headquartered in the U.S. The U.S.
has the world's highest number of billionaires, with total wealth of $5.7
trillion. U.S. commercial banks had $22.9 trillion in assets in December 2022.
U.S. global assets under management had more than $30 trillion in assets.
During the Great Recession of 2008, the U.S. economy suffered a significant
decline. The American Reinvestment and Recovery Act was enacted by the United
States Congress, and in the ensuing years the U.S. experienced the longest
economic expansion on record by July 2019.

The New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq are the world's largest stock exchanges
by market capitalization and trade volume. The U.S. has the world's largest
gold reserves, with over 8,000 tonnes of gold. In 2014, the U.S. economy was
ranked first in international ranking on venture capital and global research
and development funding. The U.S. spends around 3.46% of GDP on cutting-edge
research and development across various sectors of the economy. Consumer
spending comprised 68% of the U.S. economy in 2022, while its labor share of
income was 44% in 2021. The U.S. has the world's largest consumer market. The
nation's labor market has attracted immigrants from all over the world and its
net migration rate is among the highest in the world. The U.S. is one of the
top-performing economies in studies such as the Ease of Doing Business Index,
the Global Competitiveness Report, and others.

generated_detailed_content: The United States possesses a highly developed mixed economy, distinguished by its status as the world's largest economy by nominal gross domestic product (GDP) and the second largest by purchasing power parity (PPP) as of 2025. This dual ranking reflects the country’s immense economic output measured in current U.S. dollars and adjusted for relative cost of living and inflation rates across nations. In terms of wealth distribution on a per capita basis, the United States held the seventh highest nominal GDP per capita globally in 2025, alongside the ninth highest GDP per capita by PPP, underscoring a high standard of living relative to most other countries. These figures illustrate the substantial economic capacity of the average American citizen when compared internationally, while also highlighting the nuances of global purchasing power. Accounting for approximately 27% of the global economy in nominal terms and about 16% in PPP terms in 2025, the United States commands a significant share of worldwide economic activity. This disproportionate contribution to global GDP underscores the country's central role in international trade, finance, and economic policy. The prominence of the U.S. dollar in global finance further cements this position; it serves as the most widely used currency of record in international transactions and remains the world’s primary reserve currency. This dominance is supported by several factors, including the extensive and liquid market for U.S. Treasury securities, which are regarded as one of the safest investments globally. Additionally, the dollar’s role as the reference standard for the petrodollar system, whereby oil is priced and traded in U.S. dollars, and the linked eurodollar market, which facilitates dollar-denominated deposits outside the United States, reinforce its international stature. Several countries have officially adopted the U.S. dollar as their national currency, while in others it functions as a de facto currency alongside or instead of the local currency. This widespread use facilitates international trade and investment, providing stability and reducing currency risk for businesses and governments engaged with the United States. The dollar’s global reach is a product of historical developments, particularly following World War II, when the United States emerged as the dominant economic power. Since that time, the American economy has experienced relatively steady growth, characterized by periods of low unemployment and controlled inflation, alongside rapid technological advancements that have transformed industries and productivity. The underlying drivers of the American economy include high productivity levels, a well-developed transportation infrastructure, and abundant natural resources. Productivity gains have been fueled by innovation, capital investment, and an adaptable workforce, while the extensive network of highways, railroads, ports, and airports facilitates efficient movement of goods and people. The country’s wealth of natural resources, including fertile agricultural land, vast mineral deposits, and significant energy reserves, has historically provided a foundation for industrial and economic expansion. Reflecting this prosperity, Americans possess the sixth highest average household and employee income among member states of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). In 2021, the United States recorded the highest median household income among OECD countries, indicating that the typical American household earned more than counterparts in other developed nations. However, this economic success is tempered by one of the highest levels of income inequality among developed countries, highlighting disparities in wealth distribution and economic opportunity. The United States maintains robust trade relationships with a diverse array of countries, with its largest trading partners including Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, Germany, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Taiwan, India, and Vietnam. These partnerships facilitate the exchange of goods and services critical to the U.S. economy, ranging from raw materials and manufactured products to technology and consumer goods. The United States holds the distinction of being the world’s largest importer and the second-largest exporter of goods and services, reflecting its role as a global hub for consumption and production. To support and regulate these trade flows, the U.S. has entered into numerous free trade agreements, most notably the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and governs trade relations with its two immediate neighbors. Additional agreements with countries such as Australia, South Korea, and Israel further integrate the U.S. economy into global markets, while ongoing negotiations aim to expand and refine these trade partnerships. The U.S. labor market is characterized by a high degree of flexibility, often described as a hire-and-fire system, which allows employers to adjust their workforce relatively quickly in response to economic conditions. This flexibility is accompanied by relatively low job security compared to many other developed nations, reflecting a labor policy environment that emphasizes market responsiveness over employment protections. Despite this, the United States maintains a social security system that is considered highly efficient among OECD countries, with social expenditure amounting to roughly 30% of GDP. This social safety net encompasses programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and unemployment insurance, which provide support to various segments of the population, including retirees, the disabled, and the unemployed. In terms of natural resource production, the United States ranks as the world’s largest producer of petroleum, natural gas, and blood products. The energy sector has been a cornerstone of the American economy, with advancements in extraction technologies such as hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling contributing to increased output and energy independence. The country’s leadership in blood product production reflects a sophisticated biomedical industry that supports healthcare and medical research. By 2016, the United States had become the world’s largest trading country and the second-largest manufacturer, with American manufacturing accounting for one-fifth of the global total. This manufacturing base spans a wide range of industries, including automotive, aerospace, machinery, and electronics, underscoring the country’s industrial diversity and capacity. The United States boasts the largest internal market for goods, driven by its large population and high consumer purchasing power, and dominates the global services trade, which includes sectors such as finance, insurance, education, and healthcare. Total U.S. trade volume reached $4.2 trillion in 2018, reflecting the scale and dynamism of its international commerce. Among the world’s 500 largest companies, 139 are headquartered in the United States, illustrating the country’s role as a global corporate powerhouse. Moreover, the U.S. has the highest number of billionaires worldwide, whose combined wealth totals $5.7 trillion, highlighting the concentration of economic power and capital within the nation. The financial sector in the United States is substantial, with commercial banks holding assets totaling $22.9 trillion as of December 2022. This vast asset base supports lending, investment, and economic growth domestically and internationally. Additionally, U.S. global assets under management exceeded $30 trillion, reflecting the country’s preeminence in asset management and financial services. The resilience of the American economy was tested during the Great Recession of 2008, when it experienced a significant decline marked by widespread financial distress and economic contraction. In response, Congress enacted the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act, a stimulus package designed to promote economic recovery through government spending, tax incentives, and financial support for key sectors. Following this recession, the United States experienced the longest economic expansion on record, which lasted until July 2019. This prolonged period of growth was characterized by steady job creation, rising incomes, and low inflation, although it also saw increasing concerns about wage stagnation and economic inequality. The country’s capital markets are anchored by the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq, which stand as the world’s largest stock exchanges by market capitalization and trade volume, serving as critical venues for capital formation and investment. The United States also holds the world’s largest gold reserves, with over 8,000 tonnes of gold stored primarily at Fort Knox and other secure locations, symbolizing the country’s financial stability and economic strength. In 2014, the U.S. economy led internationally in venture capital investment and global research and development (R&D) funding, reflecting its commitment to innovation and technological advancement. The nation invests approximately 3.46% of its GDP in cutting-edge R&D across various economic sectors, fostering breakthroughs in fields such as information technology, biotechnology, aerospace, and clean energy. Consumer spending remains a dominant force in the economy, accounting for 68% of the U.S. GDP in 2022, underscoring the central role of household consumption in driving economic activity. The labor share of income in the United States was 44% in 2021, indicating the proportion of national income allocated to wages and salaries relative to capital income. The United States has the world’s largest consumer market, attracting immigrants from around the globe who contribute to the labor force and demographic growth. This inflow of immigrants has resulted in one of the highest net migration rates worldwide, enriching the country’s cultural diversity and economic dynamism. The U.S. economy consistently ranks highly in global assessments such as the Ease of Doing Business Index and the Global Competitiveness Report, reflecting a favorable environment for entrepreneurship, investment, and innovation. The comprehensive analysis of the U.S. economy encompasses its extensive history and sectoral composition. Economic history topics include agricultural history, banking history, petroleum history, shipbuilding, the Industrial Revolution, the history of the U.S. dollar, lumber history, tariff history, and economic history by state, providing a detailed understanding of the factors that have shaped the nation’s economic trajectory. The economy is examined across primary sectors such as agriculture, energy, petroleum, electricity, mining, fishing, forestry, and water and sanitation; secondary sectors including automotive, iron and steel, and pulp and paper; tertiary sectors covering social programs, transportation, tourism, education, gambling, healthcare, and insurance; and financial services, which encompass the central bank, banking institutions, the largest banks, and stock exchanges. Economic performance and characteristics are further analyzed at the state level, with detailed statistics on budgets, credit ratings, unemployment rates, and union membership for states such as California, Texas, New York, and Florida. This state-level analysis extends to cities and counties including Allentown, Atlanta, Buffalo, Chicago, Cleveland, Columbus, Detroit, Door County, Erie, Houston, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Lexington, Long Island, Louisville, Memphis, New York City, Norfolk, Omaha, Philadelphia, Phoenix, Pittsburgh, Salt Lake City, San Diego, Spokane, St. Louis, Stamford, Youngstown, and Washington, D.C., highlighting regional economic diversity and local economic conditions. Labor-related topics receive particular attention, encompassing labor law aspects such as child labor regulations, labor unions, minimum wage legislation, and right-to-work laws. Employment issues, including the causes of unemployment, are also explored, providing insight into the challenges and dynamics of the U.S. labor market. Together, these multifaceted analyses offer a comprehensive portrait of the United States economy, reflecting its complexity, scale, and global significance.

The economic history of the United States began with British settlements along
the Eastern seaboard in the 17th and 18th centuries. After 1700, the United
States gained population rapidly, and imports as well as exports grew along
with it. Africa, Asia, and most frequently Europe, contributed to the trade of
the colonies. These 13 colonies gained independence from the British Empire in
the late 18th century and quickly grew from colonial economies towards an
economy focused on agriculture.
openai_summarised_points: • The economic history of the United States originated with British settlements established along the Eastern seaboard during the 17th and 18th centuries.
• After the year 1700, the population of the American colonies increased rapidly, which corresponded with significant growth in both imports and exports.
• The colonies engaged in international trade involving Africa, Asia, and most frequently Europe, contributing to the economic development of the region.
• The 13 American colonies declared and gained independence from the British Empire in the late 18th century.
• Following independence, the economy of the former colonies transitioned from primarily colonial trade-based systems toward an economy increasingly focused on agriculture.
generated_detailed_content: The economic history of what would become the United States began with the establishment of British settlements along the Eastern seaboard during the 17th and 18th centuries. These early colonies, including Virginia, Massachusetts, Maryland, and others, were initially founded with a variety of economic motives, ranging from the pursuit of natural resources to the establishment of new markets for British goods. The settlers engaged in activities such as fishing, fur trading, and small-scale agriculture, which laid the foundational economic structures of the region. Over time, these settlements grew into more complex economies as they adapted to the diverse geographic and climatic conditions of the Atlantic coastline. After the year 1700, the population of the American colonies increased rapidly, a demographic expansion that was closely linked to significant growth in both imports and exports. This population boom was fueled by natural increase as well as continued immigration from Europe, which provided a growing labor force and consumer base. As the colonial population expanded, so too did the demand for goods, both locally produced and imported. The volume of trade surged, with exports such as tobacco, rice, indigo, and later cotton becoming increasingly important commodities in the Atlantic economy. Imports, including manufactured goods, textiles, and luxury items from Britain and other European countries, also rose sharply, reflecting the colonies’ growing integration into global trade networks. The American colonies engaged in extensive international trade that connected them not only with Europe but also with Africa and Asia, contributing significantly to the economic development of the region. The triangular trade system exemplified this global economic interaction, wherein colonial goods like rum and tobacco were shipped to Africa in exchange for enslaved people, who were then transported to the Caribbean and American colonies to work on plantations. From there, goods such as sugar and molasses were transported to Europe and North America. Additionally, the colonies imported Asian goods including spices, tea, and textiles, mainly through European intermediaries. This complex web of trade routes facilitated the flow of capital, commodities, and labor, which underpinned the economic vitality of the colonies and helped establish them as an integral part of the burgeoning Atlantic economy. In the late 18th century, the 13 American colonies declared and subsequently won their independence from the British Empire, a political transformation that had profound economic implications. The Declaration of Independence in 1776 marked the formal assertion of sovereignty, and the ensuing Revolutionary War disrupted established trade relationships and economic patterns. The colonies’ break from British rule necessitated the creation of new economic policies and institutions to support an independent nation. The war effort itself stimulated certain industries, such as domestic manufacturing, while trade restrictions and blockades compelled the colonies to become more self-reliant. The post-war period was characterized by efforts to stabilize the economy, pay off war debts, and develop internal markets free from British mercantile control. Following independence, the economy of the former colonies underwent a significant transition from primarily colonial trade-based systems toward an economy increasingly focused on agriculture. While trade remained important, the new United States saw a growing emphasis on domestic agricultural production as the backbone of its economy. The fertile lands of the interior and southern regions were cultivated extensively, producing staple crops such as wheat, corn, and cotton. This agricultural expansion was facilitated by innovations in farming techniques and the gradual displacement of Native American populations. The reliance on agriculture also shaped social and economic structures, with plantation agriculture becoming particularly dominant in the South, supported by enslaved labor. At the same time, small-scale farming and subsistence agriculture remained prevalent in other regions. The shift towards an agrarian economy laid the groundwork for future economic development and diversification in the 19th century.

In 180 years, the United States grew to become a huge, integrated, and
industrialized economy, which made up about a fifth of the world economy. In
that process, the U.S. GDP per capita rose past that of many other countries,
supplanting the British Empire at the top. The economy maintained high wages,
attracting immigrants by the millions from all over the world. In the 1820s
and 1830s, mass production shifted much of the economy from artisans to
factories. New government regulations strengthened patents.

Early in the 19th century, more than 80 percent of Americans engaged in
farming. Most of the manufacturing centered on the first stages of the
transformation of raw materials, with lumber and sawmills, textiles, and boots
and shoes leading the way. The rich natural resources contributed to the rapid
economic expansion of the nineteenth century. Ample land allowed the number of
farmers to keep growing; but activity in manufacturing, services,
transportation, and other sectors grew much faster, so that by 1860 the
population was only about 50 percent rural, down from over 80 percent.

In the 19th century, recessions frequently coincided with financial crises.
The Panic of 1837 was followed by a five-year depression, marked by bank
failures and unprecedented unemployment. Because of the great changes in the
economy over the centuries, it is difficult to compare the severity of modern
recessions to that of early recessions. Recessions after World War II appear
to have been less severe than earlier recessions, but the reasons for this are
unclear.
openai_summarised_points: • Over a span of 180 years, the United States evolved into a vast, integrated, and industrialized economy, accounting for approximately one-fifth of the global economy by the end of the period.
• During this transformation, the U.S. GDP per capita surpassed that of many other nations, overtaking the British Empire as the leading economic power.
• The U.S. economy sustained high wage levels, which attracted millions of immigrants from across the world seeking better economic opportunities.
• In the 1820s and 1830s, the rise of mass production shifted the economic focus from artisanal craftsmanship to factory-based manufacturing.
• Government regulations introduced during this era strengthened patent protections, fostering innovation and industrial growth.
• At the beginning of the 19th century, over 80 percent of the American population was engaged in farming, reflecting a predominantly agrarian society.
• Early manufacturing primarily involved initial processing of raw materials, with key industries including lumber and sawmills, textiles, and the production of boots and shoes.
• The abundance of natural resources in the United States significantly contributed to the rapid economic expansion throughout the 19th century.
• The availability of ample land allowed the farming population to continue growing; however, sectors such as manufacturing, services, and transportation expanded at a much faster rate.
• By 1860, the rural population had decreased to about 50 percent, down from over 80 percent at the start of the century, indicating increasing urbanization and industrialization.
• The 19th century experienced frequent recessions that often coincided with financial crises, exemplified by the Panic of 1837.
• The Panic of 1837 triggered a prolonged five-year depression characterized by widespread bank failures and unprecedented levels of unemployment.
• Due to the extensive economic changes over the centuries, direct comparisons between the severity of early recessions and modern recessions are challenging.
• Post-World War II recessions appear to have been less severe than those in the 19th century, although the underlying reasons for this difference remain unclear.
generated_detailed_content: Over the course of approximately 180 years, the United States underwent a profound transformation from a largely agrarian society into a vast, integrated, and industrialized economy. By the end of this period, the American economy accounted for roughly one-fifth of the global economic output, reflecting its emergence as a dominant force on the world stage. This remarkable growth was driven by a combination of factors including technological innovation, expansion of infrastructure, and the exploitation of abundant natural resources. As the economy expanded, the United States moved beyond its regional and fragmented origins to develop a cohesive national market characterized by interconnected industries and transportation networks. During this extensive economic evolution, the United States experienced a significant rise in its gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, surpassing many established nations and eventually overtaking the British Empire as the leading economic power. This shift marked a pivotal moment in global economic history, as the United States transitioned from a peripheral economy to the center of industrial and financial activity. The growth in GDP per capita not only reflected increased productivity but also indicated improvements in living standards for many Americans. This economic ascendancy was underpinned by innovations in manufacturing processes, expansion of the railroad system, and the rise of large-scale enterprises. The sustained high wage levels prevalent in the United States during this era played a crucial role in attracting millions of immigrants from around the world. Economic opportunities in burgeoning industrial centers and expanding agricultural frontiers drew people seeking better livelihoods, contributing to a diverse and rapidly growing population. Immigrants provided a vital labor force that fueled industrial growth, urbanization, and the development of new markets. This influx of human capital also facilitated cultural exchange and demographic shifts that reshaped the social fabric of the nation. In the 1820s and 1830s, the American economy witnessed a significant shift with the rise of mass production techniques, which altered the focus from artisanal craftsmanship to factory-based manufacturing. This transition was marked by the adoption of mechanized processes and the division of labor, which increased efficiency and output. Factories began to replace small workshops as centers of production, enabling the manufacture of goods on a scale previously unattainable. This period saw the emergence of industries such as textiles, ironworks, and machinery production, which laid the foundation for the United States’ industrial expansion in the decades to come. Government intervention during this transformative era included the introduction of regulations designed to strengthen patent protections. These legal frameworks encouraged innovation by securing inventors’ rights and incentivizing the development of new technologies. The establishment of a robust patent system contributed to a climate of creativity and competition, fostering industrial growth and technological advancement. Notable inventions such as the cotton gin, the telegraph, and improvements in steam engine technology were protected under these regulations, accelerating the pace of economic development. At the dawn of the 19th century, the American population was predominantly agrarian, with over 80 percent engaged in farming. This demographic reality reflected the country’s reliance on agriculture as the primary source of livelihood and economic activity. Farms were typically small-scale and family-run, producing a variety of crops and livestock for local consumption and regional markets. Despite the early dominance of agriculture, the seeds of industrialization were already being sown through the gradual expansion of manufacturing and infrastructural improvements. Early manufacturing in the United States primarily involved the initial processing of raw materials, serving as a critical link between agricultural production and finished consumer goods. Key industries during this phase included lumber and sawmills, which capitalized on the nation’s vast forest resources, as well as textiles, which processed raw cotton and wool into fabric. The production of boots and shoes also emerged as a significant manufacturing sector, supplying essential goods to a growing population. These industries laid the groundwork for more complex manufacturing activities by establishing supply chains and developing skilled labor pools. The abundance of natural resources in the United States significantly contributed to the rapid economic expansion throughout the 19th century. Vast tracts of fertile land, extensive forests, rich mineral deposits, and navigable waterways provided the raw materials necessary for industrial growth and agricultural productivity. The exploitation of these resources supported the development of industries such as mining, timber, and agriculture, which in turn fueled related sectors like transportation and manufacturing. The availability of resources not only sustained domestic economic activities but also enabled the United States to become a major exporter of raw materials and manufactured goods. The availability of ample land allowed the farming population to continue growing in absolute terms; however, sectors such as manufacturing, services, and transportation expanded at a much faster rate. This differential growth led to a gradual decline in the relative share of the population engaged in agriculture, even as the total number of farmers increased. Additionally, advancements in economic theory and data analysis have improved policymakers’ ability to respond to recessions. Nonetheless, the precise causes of the reduced severity of postwar recessions compared to their 19th-century counterparts continue to be a subject of scholarly investigation.

were towards lower prices and more output in these industries. Many workers
shared the success of these large firms, which typically offered the highest
wages in the world.

The United States has been the world's largest national economy in terms of
GDP since around 1890. For many years following the Great Depression of the
1930s, when the danger of recession appeared most serious, the government
strengthened the economy by spending heavily itself or cutting taxes so that
consumers would spend more and by fostering rapid growth in the money supply,
which also encouraged more spending. Ideas about the best tools for
stabilizing the economy changed substantially between the 1930s and the 1980s.
From the New Deal era that began in 1933 to the Great Society initiatives of
the 1960s, national policymakers relied principally on fiscal policy to
influence the economy.

During the world wars of the twentieth century, the United States fared better
than the rest of the combatants because none of the First World War and
relatively little of the Second World War were fought on American territory
(and none on the then-48 states). Yet, even in the United States, the wars
meant sacrifice. During the peak of Second World War activity, nearly 40
percent of U.S. GDP was devoted to war production. Decisions about large
swaths of the economy were largely made for military purposes, and nearly all
relevant inputs were allocated to the war effort. Many goods were rationed,
prices and wages controlled, and many durable consumer goods were no longer
produced. Large segments of the workforce were inducted into the military and
paid half their wages; roughly half of those were sent into harm's way.

The approach, advanced by British economist John Maynard Keynes, gave elected
officials a leading role in directing the economy since spending and taxes are
controlled by the U.S. president and Congress. The "Baby Boom" saw a dramatic
increase in fertility in the period 1942–1957; it was caused by delayed
marriages and childbearing during the depression years, a surge in prosperity,
a demand for suburban single-family homes (as opposed to inner city
apartments), and new optimism about the future. The boom peaked around 1957
and then began to fade. A period of high inflation, interest rates, and
unemployment after 1973 weakened confidence in fiscal policy as a tool for
regulating the overall pace of economic activity.

The U.S. economy grew by an average of 3.8% from 1946 to 1973, while real
median household income surged by 74% (or 2.1% a year).

Since the 1970s, several emerging countries have begun to close the economic

manufacture of goods formerly made in the U.S. to countries where they could
be made for sufficiently less money to cover the cost of shipping plus a
higher profit. In other cases, some countries have gradually learned to
produce the same products and services that previously only the U.S. and a few

The United States economy experienced a recession in 2001 with an unusually
slow jobs recovery, with the number of jobs not regaining the February 2001
level until January 2005. This "jobless recovery" overlapped with the building
of a housing bubble and arguably a wider debt bubble, as the ratio of
household debt to GDP rose from a record level of 70% in Q1 2001 to 99% in Q1
2008. Homeowners were borrowing against their bubble-priced homes to fuel
consumption, driving up their debt levels while providing an unsustainable
boost to GDP. When housing prices began falling in 2006, the value of
securities backed by mortgages fell dramatically, causing the equivalent of a
bank run in the essentially unregulated non-depository banking system, which
had outgrown the traditional, regulated depository banking system. Many
mortgage companies and other non-depository banks (e.g., investment banks)
faced a worsening crisis in 2007–2008, with the banking crisis peaking in
September 2008, with the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers and bailouts of several
other financial institutions.

The Bush administration (2001–2009) and Obama administrations (2009–2017)
applied banking bailout programs and Keynesian stimulus via high government
deficits, while the Federal Reserve maintained near-zero interest rates. These
measures helped the economy recover, as households paid down debts in
2009–2012, the only years since 1947 where this occurred, presenting a
significant barrier to recovery. Real GDP regained its pre-crisis (late 2007)
peak by 2011, household net worth by Q2 2012, non-farm payroll jobs by May
2014, and the unemployment rate by September 2015. Each of these variables
continued into post-recession record territory following those dates, with the
U.S. recovery becoming the second longest on record in April 2018.

The Great Recession occurred during the 2008 financial crisis, when GDP fell
by 5.0% from the spring of 2008 to the spring of 2009. Other significant
recessions took place in 1957–1958, when GDP fell 3.7% following the 1973 oil
crisis, with a 3.1% fall from late 1973 to early 1975, and in the 1981–1982
recession, when GDP dropped by 2.9%. Recent, mild recessions have included the
1990–1991 downturn, when output fell by 1.3%, and the 2001 recession, in which
GDP slid by 0.3%; the 2001 downturn lasted just eight months. The most
vigorous, sustained periods of growth, on the other hand, took place from
early 1961 to mid-1969, with an expansion of 53% (5.1% a year), from mid-1991
to late 2000, at 43% (3.8% a year), and from late 1982 to mid-1990, at 37% (4%
a year).

Debt held by the public, a measure of national debt, has risen throughout the
21st century. Rising from 31% in 2000 to 52% in 2009, and reaching 77% of GDP
in 2017, the U.S. ranked 43rd highest in debt out of 207 countries.

In the first two quarters of 2020 amid Donald Trump's presidency, the U.S.
economy suffered major setbacks beginning in March 2020, due to the novel
coronavirus and having to "shut-down" major sectors of the American economy.
As of March 2020, US exports of automobiles and industrial machines had
plummeted as a result of the worldwide pandemic. Social distancing measures
which took effect in March 2020, and which negatively impacted the demand for
goods and services, resulted in the US GDP declining at a 4.8% annualized rate
in the first quarter, the steepest pace of contraction in output since the
fourth quarter of 2008. US retails sales dropped a record 8.7% in March alone.
The US airline industry had also been hit hard, seeing a sharp decline in its
revenues. The COVID-19 recession has been widely described as the most severe
global economic downturn since the Great Depression and "far worse" than the
Great Recession.

Midtown Manhattan, the world's largest central business district

In May 2020, CNN gave an analysis based on unemployment data that the US
economy was perhaps the worst that it had been since the 1930s. By May 8, the
US had reached a record 14.7 percent unemployment, with 20.5 million jobs lost
in April. The Chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Jerome Powell, warned that
it may take "an extended time" before the US economy fully recovers from weak
economic growth, due to the pandemic, and that in the foreseeable future the
US can expect "low productivity growth and stagnant incomes". By May 31, 2020,
more than forty million Americans had filed for unemployment benefits.

By June 2020, the slump in US continental flights due to the coronavirus
pandemic had resulted in the US government temporarily halting service of
fifteen US airlines to 75 domestic airports. _The New York Times_ reported on
June 10, 2020, that "the United States budget deficit grew to a record $1.88
trillion for the first eight months of this fiscal year."

The US economy recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic in 2021, growing by 5.7%,
which was its best performance since Ronald Reagan's presidency (1981–1989).

2021–2022 marked a historical inflation surge in the United States, with the
Consumer Price Index inflation rate hitting 9.1% higher in June 2022 than June
2021, constituting a 41-year high inflation rate with critics blaming the
Federal Reserve among other factors. Inflation rate reached 4.9% in April
2023, which was roughly 3% above the Federal Reserve's 2% target rate.

generated_detailed_content: In the first half of 2020, under the administration of President Donald Trump, the United States economy encountered profound setbacks triggered by the outbreak of the novel coronavirus pandemic. Beginning in March 2020, the rapid spread of COVID-19 necessitated widespread shutdowns across major sectors of the American economy, profoundly disrupting normal commercial activity. These unprecedented public health measures, intended to curb viral transmission, resulted in significant contractions in economic output and consumer activity. The pandemic’s onset coincided with a sharp decline in international trade, particularly affecting U.S. exports of key manufactured goods. By March 2020, exports of automobiles and industrial machinery—a vital component of the nation’s trade portfolio—plummeted as global supply chains fractured and demand from foreign markets diminished due to the worldwide health crisis. The implementation of social distancing protocols in March 2020 further exacerbated economic challenges by curtailing consumer spending and limiting the operation of businesses reliant on in-person interactions. These restrictions led to a marked decrease in demand for a broad range of goods and services, contributing to a 4.8% annualized decline in the United States gross domestic product (GDP) during the first quarter of 2020. This contraction represented the steepest quarterly decline since the fourth quarter of 2008, a period marked by the global financial crisis. The economic disruption was also evident in retail sales figures, which plummeted by a record 8.7% in March 2020 alone, underscoring the severity of the downturn as consumers curtailed discretionary spending amid uncertainty and lockdown measures. Among the hardest-hit sectors was the U.S. airline industry, which experienced a precipitous drop in revenues due to travel restrictions, border closures, and a dramatic reduction in passenger demand. Airlines faced unprecedented challenges as both domestic and international travel virtually halted, leading to massive revenue losses and widespread layoffs within the industry. The economic fallout from the pandemic-induced recession was widely characterized as the most severe global downturn since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Analysts and economists noted that the COVID-19 recession’s depth and speed of onset far exceeded those of the Great Recession of 2007–2009, highlighting the extraordinary nature of the crisis. The economic impact was particularly visible in Midtown Manhattan, recognized as the world’s largest central business district, where office vacancies surged and commercial activity contracted sharply. The area’s reliance on dense office occupancy and its central role in finance, media, and corporate headquarters made it especially vulnerable to the disruptions caused by remote work mandates and reduced business travel. By May 2020, an analysis conducted by CNN of unemployment data suggested that the U.S. economy was potentially in its worst condition since the Great Depression, reflecting the scale and rapidity of job losses across multiple industries. On May 8, 2020, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a historic unemployment rate of 14.7%, the highest recorded since the Great Depression. This figure reflected the loss of 20.5 million jobs in April 2020 alone, a staggering number that underscored the immediate and devastating impact of the pandemic on the labor market. In response to the ongoing crisis, Jerome Powell, Chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve, issued warnings in May 2020 that a full economic recovery would likely require an extended period. Powell emphasized expectations of prolonged weak economic growth, low productivity growth, and stagnant incomes, signaling that the path to pre-pandemic economic conditions would be slow and uncertain. The magnitude of job losses was further illustrated by the fact that by May 31, 2020, over 40 million Americans had filed for unemployment benefits, highlighting the unprecedented scale of labor market distress. The transportation sector continued to face challenges into June 2020, as the decline in U.S. continental flights prompted the federal government to temporarily halt the services of fifteen airlines to seventy-five domestic airports. This measure aimed to consolidate air traffic and preserve the viability of the most critical routes amid drastically reduced passenger volumes. Fiscal pressures mounted alongside the economic downturn. On June 10, 2020, The New York Times reported that the U.S. budget deficit had ballooned to a record $1.88 trillion for the first eight months of the 2020 fiscal year. This historic deficit expansion reflected the combined effects of plummeting tax revenues and increased government spending on relief programs designed to mitigate the economic and public health impacts of the pandemic. Following the acute phase of the crisis, the U.S. economy began to recover in 2021, achieving a growth rate of 5.7%, the strongest annual performance since the presidency of Ronald Reagan, which spanned from 1981 to 1989. This robust rebound was driven by a combination of factors, including widespread COVID-19 vaccination efforts, fiscal stimulus measures, and the gradual reopening of businesses and consumer activity. However, the recovery period from 2021 into 2022 was accompanied by a historic surge in inflation. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation rate reached 9.1% in June 2022 compared to the same month in the previous year, marking the highest inflation rate in the United States in 41 years. This rapid increase in prices affected a broad range of goods and services, eroding purchasing power and raising concerns about the sustainability of economic growth. Critics of the inflation surge pointed to various contributing factors, including the policies of the Federal Reserve. Some analysts argued that prolonged accommodative monetary policies, such as low interest rates and asset purchases, had contributed to overheating in the economy. Others cited supply chain disruptions, labor shortages, and increased demand as additional drivers of inflationary pressures. Despite these challenges, by April 2023, the inflation rate had decreased to 4.9%, indicating a moderation from the peak levels seen in 2022. Nonetheless, this rate remained approximately 3 percentage points above the Federal Reserve’s long-term target inflation rate of 2%, suggesting that inflationary pressures continued to pose a significant concern for policymakers and the broader economy.

openai_summarised_points: • The table presents the main economic indicators of the United States from 1980 to 2023, with International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff estimates for 2024 to 2029, including GDP (both in billion US$ PPP and nominal), GDP per capita (in US$ PPP and nominal), real GDP growth, inflation rate, unemployment rate, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.

• In 1980, the US GDP was 2,857.3 billion US$ PPP and nominal, with a GDP per capita of 12,552.9 US$ PPP and nominal; the real GDP growth was −0.3%, inflation was 13.5%, unemployment was 7.2%, and government debt data was not available.

• From 1981 to 1989, GDP increased steadily from 3,207.0 billion to 5,641.6 billion US$ PPP and nominal, with GDP per capita rising from 13,948.7 to 22,814.1 US$ PPP and nominal; real GDP growth fluctuated between −1.8% and 7.2%, inflation rates decreased from 10.4% to 4.8%, unemployment declined from 7.6% to 5.3%, and government debt data remained unavailable.

• The early 1990s saw GDP growth slow, with 1991 showing a slight contraction of −0.1%, GDP at 6,158.1 billion US$, and inflation dropping to 4.2%; unemployment rose to 6.9%, and government debt data was still not reported.

• Throughout the 1990s, GDP and GDP per capita continued to grow, reaching 9,631.2 billion US$ and 34,496.2 US$ per capita in 1999, respectively; real GDP growth averaged around 2.7% to 4.8%, inflation remained below 3.4%, unemployment decreased to 4.2%, and government debt data was still not available.
• In 2000, GDP reached 10,251.0 billion US$, GDP per capita 36,312.8 US$, with 4.1% real growth, 3.4% inflation, 4.0% unemployment, and government debt at 53.1% of GDP.

• From 2001 to 2007, GDP rose from 10,581.9 billion to 14,474.3 billion US$, GDP per capita increased from 37,101.5 to 47,943.4 US$, real GDP growth varied between 1.0% and 3.9%, inflation ranged from 1.6% to 3.4%, unemployment decreased from 4.7% to 4.6%, and government debt increased from 53.1% to 64.6% of GDP.

• The 2008 financial crisis saw GDP growth nearly stagnate at 0.1%, inflation at 3.8%, unemployment rise to 5.8%, and government debt jump to 73.5% of GDP, with GDP at 14,769.9 billion US$ and GDP per capita at 48,470.6 US$.
• In 2009, GDP contracted by −2.6% to 14,478.1 billion US$, inflation was negative at −0.3% (deflation), unemployment surged to 9.3%, and government debt rose sharply to 86.7% of GDP.
• Recovery began in 2010 with GDP growth of 2.7%, inflation at 1.6%, unemployment at 9.6%, and government debt reaching 95.2% of GDP; GDP was 15,049.0 billion US$, and GDP per capita 48,586.3 US$.

• From 2011 to 2019, GDP steadily increased from 15,599.7 billion to 21,539.9 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 50,008.1 to 65,561.3 US$, real GDP growth ranged from 1.6% to 3.0%, inflation remained low between 0.1% and 3.1%, unemployment decreased significantly from 8.9% to 3.7%, and government debt rose gradually from 99.5% to 108% of GDP.

• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a GDP contraction of −2.2% to 21,354.1 billion US$, inflation was low at 1.2%, unemployment spiked to 8.1%, and government debt surged to 131.8% of GDP; GDP per capita was 64,461.6 US$.

• In 2021, GDP rebounded strongly with 6.1% growth to 23,681.1 billion US$, inflation increased to 4.7%, unemployment decreased to 5.4%, and government debt slightly declined to 124.5% of GDP; GDP per capita reached 71,257.9 US$.

• By 2022, GDP grew to 26,006.9 billion US$ with 2.5% real growth, inflation rose sharply to 8.0%, unemployment fell to 3.6%, and government debt decreased to 118.6% of GDP; GDP per capita was 77,979.8 US$.
• In 2023, GDP reached 27,720.7 billion US$, GDP per capita 82,715.1 US$, real GDP growth was 2.9%, inflation moderated to 4.1%, unemployment remained at 3.6%, and government debt was 118.7% of GDP.

• IMF staff projections for 2024 to 2029 forecast continuous GDP growth from 29,167.7 billion US$ in 2024 to 35,457.9 billion US$ in 2029, with GDP per capita rising from 86,601.2 US$ to 102,987.0 US$ over the same period.

• Projected real GDP growth rates for 2024–2029 range from 2.0% to 2.8%, inflation rates are expected to remain low between 1.9% and 2.9%, unemployment rates are forecasted between 4.0% and 4.4%, and government debt is projected to increase from 121% to 131.7% of GDP.
• Inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green in the table, indicating periods of relatively low inflation throughout the data range.
• The table also notes occurrences of deflation and year-over-year increases in the M2 money supply, though specific yearly data for these are not detailed in the summary.
generated_detailed_content: The economic indicators of the United States from 1980 through 2023, supplemented by International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff estimates for 2024 to 2029, provide a comprehensive overview of the nation’s economic trajectory over more than four decades. These indicators include gross domestic product (GDP) measured both in billion US dollars adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP) and nominal terms, GDP per capita in both PPP and nominal US dollars, real GDP growth rates, inflation rates, unemployment rates, and government debt expressed as a percentage of GDP. This extensive dataset reflects the dynamic fluctuations and trends in the U.S. economy, capturing periods of expansion, recession, inflationary pressures, and fiscal policy shifts. In 1980, the United States recorded a GDP of 2,857.3 billion US dollars in both PPP and nominal terms, with GDP per capita standing at 12,552.9 US dollars under both measures. The real GDP growth rate for that year was slightly negative at −0.3%, signaling a mild economic contraction. Inflation was notably high at 13.5%, reflecting the lingering effects of the 1970s stagflation characterized by rising prices and stagnant growth. The unemployment rate was recorded at 7.2%, indicative of labor market challenges during this period. Government debt data for 1980 was not available, leaving a gap in understanding fiscal conditions at that time. Throughout the 1980s, the U.S. economy experienced steady growth. Between 1981 and 1989, GDP expanded from 3,207.0 billion to 5,641.6 billion US dollars in both PPP and nominal terms. Correspondingly, GDP per capita increased from 13,948.7 to 22,814.1 US dollars, reflecting rising average incomes. Real GDP growth during this decade fluctuated, with rates ranging from a low of −1.8% to a high of 7.2%, illustrating periods of both recession and robust expansion. Inflation rates showed a marked decline, dropping from 10.4% in 1981 to 4.8% by 1989, as monetary policies aimed at curbing inflation took effect. Unemployment also improved, decreasing from 7.6% to 5.3%, signaling a strengthening labor market. Despite these developments, government debt data remained unavailable throughout the 1980s, limiting the analysis of fiscal trends during this decade. The early 1990s were characterized by a slowdown in economic growth. In 1991, the U.S. economy experienced a slight contraction with a real GDP growth rate of −0.1%, and GDP was recorded at 6,158.1 billion US dollars. Inflation continued its downward trend, falling to 4.2%, while unemployment rose to 6.9%, reflecting the impact of the early 1990s recession on the labor market. Government debt data was still not reported during this period, leaving fiscal conditions less transparent. The subsequent years of the 1990s saw a return to growth, with GDP and GDP per capita continuing to rise steadily. By 1999, GDP had reached 9,631.2 billion US dollars, and GDP per capita climbed to 34,496.2 US dollars. Real GDP growth averaged between 2.7% and 4.8%, indicating a period of sustained economic expansion. Inflation remained relatively low, staying below 3.4%, while unemployment rates decreased to 4.2%, reflecting a robust labor market. Government debt data was still not available for the 1990s, which limited comprehensive fiscal analysis. The year 2000 marked a significant milestone with GDP reaching 10,251.0 billion US dollars and GDP per capita rising to 36,312.8 US dollars. The real GDP growth rate was a healthy 4.1%, inflation stood at 3.4%, and unemployment was relatively low at 4.0%. For the first time in the dataset, government debt was reported, amounting to 53.1% of GDP. Between 2001 and 2007, the economy continued to grow, with GDP increasing from 10,581.9 billion to 14,474.3 billion US dollars, and GDP per capita rising from 37,101.5 to 47,943.4 US dollars. Real GDP growth during this period varied from 1.0% to 3.9%, reflecting moderate economic expansion. Inflation rates ranged from 1.6% to 3.4%, maintaining relative price stability. Unemployment rates decreased slightly, moving from 4.7% in 2001 to 4.6% in 2007, indicating a relatively stable labor market. Government debt increased from 53.1% to 64.6% of GDP, reflecting growing fiscal obligations during this period. The global financial crisis of 2008 had a profound impact on the U.S. economy. That year, GDP growth nearly stagnated at 0.1%, with GDP reaching 14,769.9 billion US dollars and GDP per capita at 48,470.6 US dollars. Inflation increased to 3.8%, while unemployment rose sharply to 5.8%, reflecting the onset of widespread job losses. Government debt surged to 73.5% of GDP as fiscal stimulus measures were implemented to counteract the economic downturn. The following year, 2009, saw a contraction in GDP by −2.6%, reducing the total to 14,478.1 billion US dollars. Inflation turned negative at −0.3%, marking a period of deflation. Unemployment surged to 9.3%, the highest level since the early 1980s, while government debt rose sharply to 86.7% of GDP, underscoring the fiscal strain caused by the recession and stimulus spending. Economic recovery began in 2010, with GDP growth rebounding to 2.7%, increasing GDP to 15,049.0 billion US dollars and GDP per capita to 48,586.3 US dollars. Inflation moderated to 1.6%, while unemployment remained elevated at 9.6%, reflecting the slow pace of labor market recovery. Government debt continued to rise, reaching 95.2% of GDP, as the government maintained fiscal support to stimulate growth. From 2011 through 2019, the U.S. economy experienced steady expansion. GDP increased from 15,599.7 billion to 21,539.9 billion US dollars, while GDP per capita rose from 50,008.1 to 65,561.3 US dollars. Real GDP growth rates during this period ranged from 1.6% to 3.0%, indicating moderate but consistent growth. Inflation remained low, fluctuating between 0.1% and 3.1%, contributing to a stable price environment. Unemployment rates decreased significantly from 8.9% in 2011 to 3.7% in 2019, reflecting a strengthening labor market. Government debt rose gradually from 99.5% to 108% of GDP, indicating ongoing fiscal challenges despite economic growth. The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a sharp economic contraction, with GDP declining by −2.2% to 21,354.1 billion US dollars. Inflation remained low at 1.2%, while unemployment spiked to 8.1% due to widespread job losses and economic disruptions. Government debt surged dramatically to 131.8% of GDP as the federal government implemented extensive fiscal stimulus measures to mitigate the pandemic’s economic impact. GDP per capita fell to 64,461.6 US dollars, reflecting the economic shock experienced by individuals. In 2021, the economy rebounded strongly, with GDP growth reaching 6.1%, pushing GDP to 23,681.1 billion US dollars and GDP per capita to 71,257.9 US dollars. Inflation increased to 4.7%, reflecting supply chain disruptions and rising demand, while unemployment decreased to 5.4% as the labor market began to recover. Government debt slightly declined to 124.5% of GDP, indicating some fiscal consolidation following the peak pandemic spending. By 2022, the U.S. economy continued to grow, with GDP reaching 26,006.9 billion US dollars and real GDP growth of 2.5%. Inflation rose sharply to 8.0%, driven by ongoing supply constraints and energy price increases. Unemployment fell further to 3.6%, reflecting a tightening labor market. Government debt decreased to 118.6% of GDP, suggesting some stabilization in fiscal balances. GDP per capita increased to 77,979.8 US dollars, underscoring rising average incomes despite inflationary pressures. In 2023, GDP reached 27,720.7 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita at 82,715.1 US dollars. Real GDP growth was recorded at 2.9%, while inflation moderated to 4.1%. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.6%, and government debt was virtually unchanged at 118.7% of GDP, indicating a period of relative economic stability. IMF staff projections for the period from 2024 to 2029 forecast continuous GDP growth, with GDP expected to increase from 29,167.7 billion US dollars in 2024 to 35,457.9 billion US dollars by 2029. GDP per capita is projected to rise from 86,601.2 US dollars to 102,987.0 US dollars over the same period, reflecting anticipated improvements in productivity and income levels. Projected real GDP growth rates range between 2.0% and 2.8%, suggesting moderate but steady economic expansion. Inflation rates are expected to remain low, fluctuating between 1.9% and 2.9%, consistent with the Federal Reserve’s inflation targeting goals. Unemployment rates are forecasted to remain relatively stable, ranging from 4.0% to 4.4%, indicating a balanced labor market. Government debt is projected to increase from 121% to 131.7% of GDP, highlighting ongoing fiscal challenges and the need for sustainable debt management policies. Throughout the dataset, inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green, indicating periods of relatively low inflation that contributed to economic stability. The table also notes occurrences of deflation, such as in 2009 when inflation was −0.3%, and tracks year-over-year increases in the M2 money supply, although specific yearly data for these monetary aggregates are not detailed in the summary. These monetary indicators provide additional context for understanding the broader economic environment, including liquidity conditions and potential inflationary or deflationary pressures. Collectively, these economic indicators offer a detailed picture of the United States’ economic performance, challenges, and outlook over the past four decades and into the near future.

generated_detailed_content: In the third quarter of 2023, private sector workers in the United States earned approximately $2 trillion, which represented about 29.6% of all money earned before taxes during that quarter. This figure underscores the significant contribution of private sector labor income to the overall economy, reflecting the earnings generated through wages, salaries, and other compensation before the deduction of taxes. The private sector’s share of income highlights its central role in driving economic activity and supporting consumer spending, which is a major component of the nation’s gross domestic product (GDP). The U.S. nominal GDP stood at $19.5 trillion in 2017, solidifying its position as the largest economy in the world by nominal terms at that time. Nominal GDP measures the total market value of all final goods and services produced within a country’s borders without adjusting for inflation, providing a snapshot of economic size and output. This substantial figure reflected the United States’ extensive economic infrastructure, diverse industries, and high levels of productivity. By the first quarter of 2018, the annualized nominal GDP of the United States had reached $20.1 trillion, marking a historic milestone as the first time the economy exceeded the $20 trillion threshold. This milestone was indicative of continued economic expansion and growth in various sectors, including technology, services, and manufacturing. The composition of U.S. GDP reveals the underlying drivers of economic activity, with approximately 70% attributed to personal consumption. This dominant share reflects the importance of consumer spending on goods and services, including durable goods, nondurable goods, and services, as a primary engine of economic growth. Business investment accounted for about 18% of GDP, encompassing expenditures on equipment, structures, and intellectual property products that contribute to future productive capacity. Government spending, which includes federal, state, and local expenditures but excludes transfer payments such as Social Security, made up around 17% of GDP. U1-U6 unemployment rate

As of December 2017, the unemployment rate in the U.S. was 4.1% or 6.6 million
people. The government's broader U-6 unemployment rate, which includes the
part-time underemployed, was 8.1% or 8.2 million people. These figures were
calculated with a civilian labor force of approximately 160.6 million people,
relative to a U.S. population of approximately 327 million people.

Between 2009 and 2010, following the Great Recession, the emerging problem of
jobless recoveries resulted in record levels of long-term unemployment with
more than six million workers looking for work for more than six months as of
January 2010. This particularly affected older workers. A year after the
recession ended in June 2009, immigrants gained 656,000 jobs in the U.S.,
while U.S.-born workers lost more than a million jobs, due in part to an aging
country (relatively more white retirees) and demographic shifts. In April
2010, the official unemployment rate was 9.9%, but the government's broader
U-6 unemployment rate was 17.1%. Between February 2008 and February 2010, the
number of people working part-time for economic reasons (i.e., would prefer to
work full-time) increased by 4.0 million to 8.8 million, an 83% increase in
part-time workers during the two-year period.

By 2013, although the unemployment rate had fallen below 8%, the record
proportion of long term unemployed and continued decreasing household income
remained indicative of a jobless recovery. However, the number of payroll jobs
returned to its pre-recession (November 2007) level by May 2014 as the economy
recovered.

After being higher in the post-war period, the U.S. unemployment rate fell
below the rising eurozone unemployment rate in the mid-1980s and has remained
significantly lower almost continuously since. In 1955, 55% of Americans
worked in services, between 30% and 35% in industry, and between 10% and 15%
in agriculture. By 1980, over 65% were employed in services, between 25% and
30% in industry, and less than 5% in agriculture. Male unemployment continued
to be significantly higher than those of females (at 9.8% vs. 7.5% in 2009).
The unemployment among Caucasians continues being much lower than those for
African-Americans (at 8.5% vs. 15.8% also in 2009).

The youth unemployment rate was 18.5% in July 2009, the highest rate in that
month since 1948. The unemployment rate of young African Americans was 28.2%

During these three decades, income distribution became more equitable, driven by factors such as strong labor unions, progressive taxation, and broad-based economic growth that lifted wages across the socioeconomic spectrum. However, from the 1980s onward, the United States experienced a reversal of this trend, entering a phase known as the great divergence, characterized by a steady and significant increase in income inequality that has persisted into the twenty-first century. When compared to other post-industrialized peer countries, the United States consistently exhibits the highest level of income inequality. While pre-tax and transfer income inequality in the U.S. is roughly comparable to that of other developed nations, the divergence becomes more pronounced after accounting for taxes and government transfers. This suggests that the U.S. has a less redistributive fiscal system, with lower levels of income redistribution from higher-income households to lower-income households relative to its international counterparts. In many other advanced economies, progressive taxation and more generous social welfare programs serve to substantially reduce income disparities, whereas the U.S. system results in a greater persistence of inequality after government intervention. In 2016, the disparities in income across different segments of the U.S. population were starkly evident in average market income figures. The lowest income quintile, representing the bottom 20% of earners, had an average market income of approximately $15,600. In contrast, the highest income quintile, comprising the top 20% of earners, averaged $280,300, highlighting a substantial gap between the lower and upper ends of the income distribution. Within this highest quintile, inequality was even more pronounced, as the top 1% of earners reported an average income of about $1.8 million. This figure was roughly 30 times greater than the $59,300 average income of the middle quintile, underscoring the concentration of wealth at the very top of the income hierarchy. The economic and political consequences of such income inequality in the United States are multifaceted and significant. From an economic perspective, elevated inequality has been linked to slower gross domestic product (GDP) growth, as a large portion of income concentrated among the wealthy may lead to underconsumption and reduced aggregate demand. Additionally, higher inequality correlates with diminished income mobility, meaning that individuals born into lower-income families face greater challenges in improving their economic status over their lifetimes. Elevated poverty rates are another consequence, as income disparities contribute to persistent economic hardship for significant segments of the population. Furthermore, increased reliance on household debt among lower- and middle-income families raises the risk of financial crises, as indebtedness can amplify economic vulnerabilities during downturns. Politically, rising inequality has been associated with heightened polarization, as economic divides translate into divergent political interests and social fragmentation. Several factors have contributed to the rise in income inequality in the United States over recent decades. One prominent driver has been the increasing compensation of executives relative to average workers, with top corporate leaders receiving disproportionately large salaries, bonuses, and stock options. The financialization of the economy, characterized by the growing dominance of the financial sector and its influence on corporate behavior, has also played a role in exacerbating income disparities. Greater industry concentration, where a few large firms dominate markets, has reduced competition and bargaining power for workers, further skewing income distribution. Declining unionization rates have weakened collective bargaining and labor protections, diminishing wage growth for many workers. Additionally, lower effective tax rates on higher incomes have reduced the redistributive impact of the tax system. Technological changes have favored individuals with higher educational attainment, as automation and digital innovation have increased demand for skilled labor while displacing lower-skilled jobs, thereby widening income gaps based on education and skill levels. Measuring income inequality in the United States involves methodological complexities and ongoing debates, as different datasets and definitions of income yield varying results. A key distinction lies in whether income is measured as cash compensation before government intervention (market income) or after accounting for taxes and transfers (disposable income). The Gini coefficient is a widely accepted statistical measure used to quantify income inequality, with values ranging from 0, indicating perfect equality where all individuals have identical incomes, to 1, representing maximum inequality where a single individual holds all income. Variations in data sources and income definitions can influence the calculated Gini coefficient, necessitating careful interpretation of inequality metrics. Primary sources of data for assessing income inequality in the United States include the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), and the U.S. Census Bureau. According to the Census Bureau, the Gini coefficient for pre-tax money income reached a record high of 0.485 in 2018, signaling a significant level of income disparity. This trend continued with the coefficient rising to 0.488 in 2020 and further to 0.494 in 2021, reflecting a persistent increase in income inequality over recent years. These figures underscore the growing concentration of income among higher earners and the challenges in achieving a more equitable distribution. U.S. tax and transfer policies are generally progressive in nature, designed to reduce effective income inequality by imposing higher tax rates on higher income brackets. The tax code includes mechanisms such as graduated income tax rates, capital gains taxes, and estate taxes that aim to redistribute income. Additionally, the lowest earning workers, particularly those with dependents, often pay no federal income taxes due to standard deductions, exemptions, and credits. Programs such as the Child Tax Credit and the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) provide subsidies and direct financial support to low-income families, enhancing their disposable income and mitigating poverty. These policies collectively serve to reduce income disparities, although the extent of redistribution remains less pronounced compared to many other developed countries. Data from the Congressional Budget Office further illustrate the redistributive effects of fiscal policy on income inequality. In 2016, the U.S. Gini coefficient based on market income was estimated at 0.59, indicating a high level of inequality prior to government intervention. After accounting for the impact of taxes and transfers, the Gini coefficient decreased substantially to 0.42, demonstrating the significant role that fiscal policy plays in reducing income disparities. This reduction highlights the importance of government programs and taxation in shaping the overall distribution of income within the country. The share of market income accruing to the top 1% of earners has undergone notable changes over recent decades. In 1979, this group received 9.6% of total market income, a figure that rose sharply to a peak of 20.7% in 2007, reflecting the increasing concentration of wealth at the uppermost tier of the income distribution. Following the 2007 peak, the top 1% share declined somewhat to 17.5% by 2016, indicating some degree of fluctuation in income concentration. When considering income after taxes and transfers, these shares were lower, with the top 1% accounting for 7.4% of income in 1979, rising to 16.6% in 2007, and then decreasing to 12.5% in 2016. These figures reveal the mitigating effects of taxation and social programs on the distribution of income, although the top 1% still retains a disproportionately large share of total income.

As of Q4 2017, total household net worth in the United States was a record $99
trillion, an increase of $5.2 trillion from 2016. This increase reflects both
stock market and housing price gains. This measure has been setting records
since Q4 2012. If divided evenly, the $99 trillion represents an average of

person. However, median household net worth (i.e., half of the families above
and below this level) was $97,300 in 2016. The bottom 25% of families had a
median net worth of zero, while the 25th to 50th percentile had a median net
worth of $40,000.

Wealth inequality is more unequal than income inequality, with the top 1%
households owning approximately 42% of the net worth in 2012, versus 24% in
1979. According to a September 2017 report by the Federal Reserve, wealth
inequality is at record highs; the top 1% controlled 38.6% of the country's
wealth in 2016. The Boston Consulting Group posited in June 2017 report that
1% of the Americans will control 70% of country's wealth by 2021.

The top 10% wealthiest possess 80% of all financial assets. Wealth inequality
in the U.S. is greater than in most developed countries other than Sweden.
Inherited wealth may help explain why many Americans who have become rich may
have had a "substantial head start". In September 2012, according to the
Institute for Policy Studies, "over 60 percent" of the Forbes richest 400
Americans "grew up in substantial privilege". Median household wealth fell 35%
in the U.S., from $106,591 to $68,839 between 2005 and 2011, due to the Great
Recession, but has since recovered as indicated above.

About 30% of the entire world's millionaire population resides in the United
States (as of 2009[update]). The Economist Intelligence Unit estimated in 2008
that there were 16,600,000 millionaires in the U.S. Furthermore, 34% of the
world's billionaires are American (in 2011).

Notably, this milestone was not an isolated event; the total household net worth had been setting new records continuously since the fourth quarter of 2012, indicating a sustained period of wealth growth following the recovery from the Great Recession. On a per capita basis, this translates to roughly $302,000 per person, suggesting a high level of wealth accumulation across the population. However, these averages mask significant disparities in wealth distribution. The median household net worth, which represents the midpoint where half of U.S. families have net worth above and half below, was considerably lower at $97,300 in 2016. In 2012, the top 1% of households owned approximately 42% of the nation’s net worth, a dramatic increase from 24% in 1979. This trend indicates a growing concentration of wealth among the very richest Americans over several decades. A report released by the Federal Reserve in September 2017 reinforced this observation, noting that wealth inequality had reached record highs, with the top 1% controlling 38.6% of the country’s wealth in 2016. When compared internationally, wealth inequality in the United States exceeds that of most developed countries, with the notable exception of Sweden. This suggests that the U.S. stands out among advanced economies for its particularly high degree of wealth concentration, which has implications for social policy, economic stability, and political dynamics. One significant factor contributing to these disparities is inherited wealth. Many wealthy Americans have benefited from a "substantial head start," with wealth passed down through generations, reinforcing existing economic advantages. A report by the Institute for Policy Studies in September 2012 highlighted that over 60% of the Forbes richest 400 Americans grew up in substantial privilege, illustrating the role of family wealth and social capital in perpetuating economic inequality. The impact of economic downturns on household wealth is also evident in historical data. Median household wealth declined by 35% from $106,591 in 2005 to $68,839 in 2011, largely as a result of the Great Recession, which severely affected asset values, employment, and income. However, subsequent data indicate a recovery in wealth levels, as reflected in the rising total household net worth figures in the years following the recession. This recovery has been uneven, with gains concentrated among wealthier households, further exacerbating wealth disparities. The United States also holds a significant share of the global millionaire population. As of 2009, approximately 30% of the world’s millionaires resided in the U.S., highlighting the country’s role as a major center of wealth accumulation. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimated in 2008 that there were around 16.6 million millionaires in the United States, underscoring the scale of wealth concentration within its borders. Additionally, in 2011, 34% of the world’s billionaires were American, further demonstrating the prominence of the U.S. in global wealth rankings and the concentration of extreme wealth within its economy.

In one study by ATTOM Data Solutions, in 70% of the counties surveyed, homes
are increasingly unaffordable for the average U.S. worker.

As of 2018, the number of U.S. citizens residing in their vehicles increased
in major cities with significantly higher than average housing costs such as
Los Angeles, Portland and San Francisco.

US$199,200. By February 2023, the median U.S. home sale price grew to

the pandemic.

As of January 2024, in roughly half of cities in the U.S., workers need

housing prices and interest rate hikes.
